items.title: WIG20 przełamuje wieloletnie rekordy. Banki i Orlen motorem wzrostów
items.snippet: Warszawska giełda zanotowała we wtorek znaczące wzrosty. WIG20 osiągnął najwyższy poziom od 2011 roku, zyskując 2,86 proc. przy obrotach przekraczających 1,86 miliarda złotych. Indeks szerokiego rynku wzrósł o 2,37 proc., generując obroty na poziomie niemal 2,90 miliarda złotych. Wyjątkową siłę pokazał sektor bankowy, którego indeks urósł o 4,13 proc. przy obrotach sięgających 764 milionów złotych. Wszystkie banki z indeksu WIG20 zakończyły sesję na plusie. Alior Bank zyskał 4,36 proc., mBank wzrósł o 3,92 proc., a Santander umocnił się o 3,53 proc. Na szczególną uwagę zasługują wzrosty największych banków - Pekao i PKO BP, które zyskały odpowiednio 5,32 proc. i 4,16 proc. Orlen również pokazał imponującą formę, drożejąc o 4,74 proc. Te trzy spółki wygenerowały łącznie około 936 milionów złotych obrotu, co stanowiło około połowy całkowitej aktywności w WIG20.

items.title: WIG20 walczy o utrzymanie 2200 pkt
items.snippet: Dzisiaj z Azji płyną pozytywne sygnały. Wszędzie dominuje zieleń, której najmocniejszy odcień widać na Tajwanie. Mocno rosną giełdy w Sydney oraz Seulu. Także w Tokio trwa ponowna walka o wypchnięcie Nikkei 225 powyżej 40000 pkt, ale do oporu pozostało jeszcze sporo miejsca. Najbardziej zdystansowany do wzrostów pozostaje parkiet w Szanghaju.

items.title: Analitycy prognozują: Orlen z największym wzrostem zysku w 2025 r.
items.snippet: Analitycy prognozują, że w 2025 roku największy wzrost zysku wśród spółek z WIG20 osiągnie Orlen, z wynikiem 14,586 mln zł. W 2024 roku zysk netto Orlen wyniósł 7,996 mln zł. Wśród innych spółek z WIG20, PKO BP osiągnie zysk netto na poziomie 10,206 mln zł w 2025 roku, a PZU 5,503 mln zł. KGHM prognozuje zysk netto na poziomie 3,470 mln zł w 2025 roku, a CD Projekt 227 mln zł.

items.title: Donald Trump's tariffs send global stocks lower as markets weigh impact
items.snippet:
Global stock markets declined on Friday, August 1, 2025, following the U.S.'s announcement of new trade tariffs under President Donald Trump. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite dropped by 1.7% and 1.9%, respectively, with Amazon shares falling sharply by 7.9% due to weak earnings. European markets also reacted negatively, with Germany's DAX falling 2.7% and France's CAC 40 down 2.9%. The wider Stoxx 600 index dipped 1.9% as investors reassessed the impact of renewed trade tensions.

The tariffs, some tougher than anticipated—particularly for Switzerland—sparked concern about global trade disruption. Analysts indicated that markets, which had recently surged on strong tech earnings and optimism around trade deals, were undergoing a "reality check" and experiencing healthy profit-taking ahead of the summer. Despite economic optimism earlier, weaker-than-expected U.S. jobs data led to a rally in government bonds, prompting speculation that the Federal Reserve may cut interest rates sooner. Yields on U.S. Treasury bonds dropped significantly, and similar moves were observed in UK and German bond markets.

items.title: Alphabet's CapitalG, Nvidia in talks to fund Vast Data at up to $30 billion valuation, sources say
items.snippet:
Alphabet's growth-stage venture arm CapitalG and Nvidia are reportedly in talks to invest in Vast Data, a startup specializing in AI infrastructure, in a funding round that could value the company at up to $30 billion. This substantial investment round, which includes tech giants, private equity, and venture capital firms, highlights the increasing value of data infrastructure providers amid the AI boom. Vast Data, headquartered in New York, offers storage technology tailored for AI data centers, facilitating efficient data transfer between GPUs such as those made by Nvidia. Its clients include xAI and CoreWeave.

The company, which had earned $200 million in annual recurring revenue by early 2025 and is projecting $600 million for the next year, is also reportedly free cash flow positive. It has raised approximately $380 million to date and was last valued at $9.1 billion in 2023. Analysts view Vast Data as a strong IPO candidate; the hiring of former Shopify CFO Amy Shapero suggests potential IPO preparations. Meanwhile, Nvidia, a potential investor, has been expanding through acquisitions to bolster its AI ecosystem, including firms like Mellanox and Run:ai. Industry experts say Vast Data's technology is more advanced compared to its rivals.

items.title: Will AI put fiction writers out of work?
items.snippet:
The growing influence of AI in creative industries has sparked controversy, particularly in literature. A prediction by Philip Stone from Nielsen that AI might produce a bestseller by 2030 stirred backlash in the UK publishing scene. Though Stone's comment was about simple formats like coloring or joke books, many feared broader implications for fiction writers. Concerns stem from AI models having been trained on authors' works without consent, and fears AI-generated text could replace human fiction.

Many prominent authors argue that AI lacks the emotional depth and unique perspective necessary for storytelling. Writers like Naomi Alderman and Sarah Hall criticize the UK government's weak regulatory framework, which permits AI firms access to creative works unless opted out. They emphasize that fiction is rooted in human experience, which AI cannot replicate.

Some authors experimented with AI writing, finding the results lacking in character and emotional resonance. While AI may be capable of generating formulaic genre fiction, it still cannot produce complex, original narratives or memoirs. In response, authors are advocating for labeling human-written content to preserve authenticity.

Though AI-generated books exist, human storytelling—deep, unpredictable, and emotionally rich—remains irreplaceable, at least for now.

items.title: Robinhood CEO: Human traders are safe from AI
items.snippet:
Robinhood CEO Vlad Tenev has expressed confidence that human traders will not be replaced by AI in the near future, despite widespread concerns about artificial intelligence disrupting white-collar jobs. Speaking to Axios, Tenev emphasized that trading remains a deeply human activity that people enjoy, suggesting that human decision-making will continue to play a central role in the financial sector.

His remarks come as AI companies increasingly target financial services as a key area for automation. However, industry voices like George Sivulka, CEO of AI finance platform Hebbia, note that successful analysts are often those who leverage AI tools to gain a competitive edge, rather than being replaced by them.

Robinhood, which already integrates AI in its investor services, sees a future where human insight and AI-driven tools coexist, potentially shaping the next evolution of investing without removing the human element.

items.title: McDonald's plans to 'double down' on AI investment by 2027, senior exec says
items.snippet: McDonald's plans to significantly increase its investment in artificial intelligence (AI) by 2027, focusing on expanding its capabilities in data governance, engineering, and platform architecture, particularly in India. Deshant Kaila, the company’s head of Global Business Services operations, stated that while precise investment figures are not yet defined due to the early stage of the initiative, the primary expenditure will be directed toward technology and tools rather than expanding staff. The strategy underscores McDonald’s commitment to leveraging AI for business transformation and identifies India as a strategic hub for developing its AI infrastructure.

items.title: Big Tech's acquihire deals face regulatory scrutiny, outgoing EU antitrust official says
items.snippet:
The outgoing head of the European Commission's antitrust unit, Olivier Guersent, stated that Big Tech's "acquihire" strategies—where tech giants hire key personnel from startups instead of acquiring the companies—are coming under increasing regulatory scrutiny. These maneuvers have largely avoided merger regulations, but Guersent emphasized that hiring staff, especially founders and senior executives, can constitute a merger since staff form part of a company’s assets. He highlighted several examples, including Microsoft’s $650 million deal to hire most of AI startup Inflection’s staff, Google’s hiring from Character.AI and Windsurf, Amazon’s acquisition of AI firm Adept’s team, and Meta’s recruitment of Scale AI’s CEO.

To tighten oversight, Guersent mentioned the European Commission's efforts to encourage member states with "call-in powers" to refer such below-threshold deals to EU regulators. Countries like Denmark, Italy, and Ireland are among those capable of doing this. Guersent, a key architect of the EU’s Digital Markets Act aimed at limiting Big Tech dominance, acknowledged the Act's progress but noted that full success remains a work in progress.

items.title: Polish (WIG) Market Analysis & Valuation - Updated Today
items.snippet: The WIG20 index, representing the top 20 companies listed on the Warsaw Stock Exchange (WSE), exhibits a financial outlook that is closely tied to the economic health of Poland and the broader European Union.

items.title: AI's spend cycle
items.snippet:
The August 1, 2025 edition of Axios AI+ covers the intensifying AI spend cycle, focusing on massive investments by major tech firms. OpenAI has raised $8.3 billion at a $300 billion valuation, with growing annual recurring revenue of $13 billion and 5 million business subscribers for ChatGPT. Tech giants like Microsoft, Google, Meta, and Apple are reinvesting AI revenues into infrastructure, driving Nvidia's market value to $4 trillion. Microsoft alone plans $100 billion in capital expenses next year, mostly AI-driven. Despite strong earnings from some companies, investor skepticism remains, especially with Amazon’s AI strategy.

A secondary focus is corporate data leakage via generative AI tools. According to Harmonic Security, 4.4% of AI prompts and 22% of uploaded files contained sensitive corporate data in Q2 2025. Many employees use AI tools without policy oversight, exposing proprietary information through services like ChatGPT, Claude, and Canva.

Also, Apple beat revenue and earnings forecasts thanks to strong iPhone sales and early purchases due to anticipated tariffs, though it faces political pressure over production location. Additional notes include OpenAI removing public conversation sharing, the Gemini 2.5 Deep Think release, Figma’s IPO success, and a sea mammal rescue highlight.

items.title: Fidelity unveils stocks to target for the rest of 2025
items.snippet: Fidelity has released a stock screen highlighting top growth, value, and income stocks that could perform well in 2025. The list includes companies like PepsiCo, which remains a dividend king with over 50 consecutive years of dividend increases, and others poised for significant performance this year.

items.title: Investors glimpse pay-off for Big Tech's mammoth spending on AI arms race
items.snippet:
Big Tech companies are beginning to realize returns on their substantial investments in artificial intelligence (AI), leading to a surge in investor confidence and market valuations. Microsoft, Alphabet, and Meta collectively added over $350 billion in market value, with Microsoft hitting a $4 trillion valuation and Meta nearing $2 trillion. Strong growth in cloud computing and advertising efficiency, attributed to AI innovations, has justified continued high capital expenditures, projected to exceed $400 billion in 2026.

Microsoft plans to invest $120 billion in the coming year to expand its data center capacity, while Meta announced a $105 billion capex for a massive new facility in Louisiana and is aggressively hiring for its AI lab. Investors are now more receptive to AI-related spending, especially as companies demonstrate profitability from the technology.

However, Amazon lagged, with its stock falling 7% due to slower AWS growth despite high spending. Apple showed resilience in iPhone sales and promised further AI investment, though its stock remained flat amid geopolitical risks. Antitrust challenges remain a significant threat, particularly for Alphabet, which faces potential divestitures.

items.title: Microsoft's in the $4 trillion club: Why Big Tech may have a problem.
items.snippet: As of July 2025, Microsoft has joined the exclusive $4 trillion market valuation club, alongside Nvidia, placing it among the top tech giants by market cap. Other major companies from the “Magnificent 7” — including Apple, Amazon, Alphabet, and Meta — are closing in on this milestone. This surge in valuation, driven by booming AI-related growth and strong earnings (particularly from Microsoft and Meta), is raising concerns among investors. Some analysts warn that Microsoft's high valuation—trading at 40 times forward earnings—may be unsustainable, and that such inflated stocks are typically vulnerable during market downturns. Despite these concerns, investor enthusiasm remains strong, continuing to push valuations higher. The article underlines the increasing tension between rapid tech growth and the risks posed by soaring market caps approaching the scale of global economies.

items.title: The 10 Best Tech Stocks of All Time
items.snippet: This article explores the 10 best tech stocks of all time, highlighting their exceptional long-term performance and contribution to overall market wealth creation. Citing research by Arizona State University’s Hendrik Bessembinder, it emphasizes that just 4% of stocks created all $34.8 trillion in shareholder wealth over a 90-year span, with tech stocks accounting for a significant portion. The top 10 were selected based on annualized total returns over at least 20 years and include both traditional and tech-adjacent firms. The list, ranked in reverse performance order, features: - Apple (AAPL): Revolutionized consumer tech with the iPhone and other products. - Amphenol (APH): A hidden AI-driven interconnect technology player. - Salesforce (CRM): A cloud services pioneer now further expanding into AI. - Fair Isaac (FICO): A dominant player in credit scoring and financial AI. - Microsoft (MSFT): Rejuvenated by its cloud and enterprise pivot. - Alphabet (GOOGL): A search and mobile OS leader investing heavily in AI. - Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR): Supplies power solutions for AI data centers. - Amazon (AMZN): Grew from e-commerce to cloud and AI leadership. - Netflix (NFLX): Streaming content leader with staggering long-term returns. - Nvidia (NVDA): The top performer, riding massive AI-driven GPU demand. The piece concludes with a caution about the difficulty of picking out such winners and endorses diversified, low-cost index fund investing.

items.title: Top Shares to Buy Today: Expert Stock Picks – Kenneth Keith's Blog
items.snippet: Bank of America has shared its top stock picks for the quarter, despite the market’s ups and downs. They highlight stocks like Spotify Technology S.A. (SPOT), The Progressive Corporation (PGR), and Alphabet, Inc. (GOOG, GOOGL). These stocks stand out for their growth potential and unique factors. Spotify Technology S.A. (SPOT): Spotify leads in audio streaming and has seen its shares jump 68% in 2024 and 224% over two years. Bank of America sees a 21% upside potential for Spotify, showing strong confidence in its future. Its strong partnerships, growing user base, and revenue diversification make it a top pick. The Progressive Corporation (PGR): The Progressive Corporation is a top pick for Bank of America. It’s a leading auto insurer known for its solid finances and growth potential. This makes it a great choice for investors looking for steady dividends and long-term gains. Alphabet, Inc. (GOOG, GOOGL): Alphabet, the parent of Google, is a favorite among Bank of America’s picks. Its strong market position, innovative products, and solid finances appeal to tech investors. Despite a 4% drop in April, Alphabet has seen an 11% increase this year, showing its resilience and growth potential. Bank of America’s picks for the quarter offer a mix of growth, stability, and income potential. These stocks can help investors understand the bank’s strategy and find new opportunities for their portfolios.

items.title: Morgan Stanley reveals top stock picks, including Nvidia
items.snippet: Morgan Stanley has shared its top stock picks, including Apple (AAPL), DraftKings (DKNG), and Eli Lilly (LLY). Apple is considered a leader in consumer electronics with a focus on a premium ecosystem of hardware, software, and services. DraftKings has extended its leading daily fantasy sports position into one of the top positions in the North American sports betting and iGaming market. Eli Lilly's innovative culture and strong financial commitment to developing the next generation of drugs set the company apart from its peers and fuel its long-term growth.

items.title: 5 Undervalued Stocks to Buy Now
items.snippet: This article highlights five undervalued stocks worth considering amid a market upswing that has left major indices at or near record highs. Despite the S&P 500's lofty valuation (forward P/E over 22), select mid-cap and small-cap stocks remain attractively priced. The chosen stocks span different sectors and were selected based on strict criteria: strong analyst Buy ratings (average ≤2.0), forward P/E ratios below sector averages, PEG ratios under 1.0 (indicating undervaluation relative to growth), and positive price performance over the past year. The five highlighted stocks are: Primo Brands (PRMB), Opera Limited (OPRA), Citizens Financial Group (CFG), CarGurus (CARG), and Chart Industries (GTLS). These selections reflect a blend of growth, value, and income opportunities across diverse industries.

Zapytania zawężają czas i sekcje giełdowe, by uzyskać krótkoterminowe, wysokiego wpływu i wiarygodne informacje do działań.
expected_signals: Wzmianki o silnych ruchach WIG20 (>±2%) i liderach/laggardach sesji
Breaking news ze spółek z WIG20/mWIG40: wyniki kwartalne, guidance, wezwania, M&A, buyback, dywidendy
Komunikaty ESPI/EBI o istotnym znaczeniu (ostrzeżenia o zysku/stracie, kontrakty, finansowanie)
Decyzje/komentarze RPP, inflacja CPI flash GUS, dane makro PL/EU wpływające na stopy i złotego
Wpływ globalny: rentowności UST/ Bund, decyzje Fed/ECB, ceny ropy/gazu, sentyment USA/Europa
Ruchy na PLN (USD/PLN, EUR/PLN) skorelowane z GPW oraz przepływy do ETF-ów na Polskę
Zmiany regulacyjne/techniczne GPW (np. krótszy cykl rozliczeń T+1, zmiany w indeksach, free float)
Analityczne przeglądy poranne i zamknięcia sesji z PB/PAP/Bankier z komentarzem strategów

decision.reason: Mam tylko jeden podglądowy artykuł o obronie 2200 pkt na WIG20, bez szerszego potwierdzenia ruchów indeksów, sygnałów ze spółek czy makro w ostatnich 48h. Brak wystarczających, jednoznacznych i nowych sygnałów wymagających natychmiastowego zatrzymania.
